entry.title: Organic ''Safari'' Trail Mix
entry.summary:
Vendor: OnlineOrganics
Type: Candies & Snacks
Price: 183.80

Our organic "Safari" trail mix is a perfect snack for lunches and all your outdoor activities. Everything is organic and there is no added salt, just pure goodness!

 

This trail mix contains:

  • Organic raisins
  • Organic pumpkin seeds
  • Organic almonds
  • Organic cashews

Locally made in Canada, buying our organic "Safari" trail mix encourages local businesses and reduces pollution from long-distance transportation.



Storage Tips:

  • Nothing beats vacuum sealing for freshness.
  • Store below 15°C and < 65% humidity.
  • Store in the dark as light degrades flavors.
  • Mason jars make great storage containers.
  • Can be frozen to prolong shelf life.

entry.title: Organic Diced Crystallized Ginger (Cane Sugar Coated)
entry.summary:
Vendor: OnlineOrganics
Type: Candies & Snacks
Price: 161.80

Our organic diced crystallized ginger makes a perfect snack and can be added to yogurt, salads, granola bars and baked goods for some chewy goodness. These cubes are 16-18 mm in size.

 

What is crystallized ginger?

  • Crystallized ginger starts with fresh ginger root which has been peeled, cut up, boiled, cooked in a thick simple syrup and then allowed to dry. The result is a crackly glaze with a soft and chewy center. A sprinkle of coarse sugar gives the ginger its crystalline finish for a sweet and tangy treat.



Storage Tips:

  • Nothing beats vacuum sealing for freshness.
  • Store below 15°C and < 65% humidity.
  • Store in the dark as light degrades flavors.
  • Mason jars make great storage containers.
  • Can be frozen to prolong shelf life.

entry.title: Organic Chocolate Covered Cocoa Nibs 70%
entry.summary:
Vendor: OnlineOrganics
Type: Candies & Snacks
Price: 74.10

Our organic dark chocolate covered cocoa nibs are whole cocoa nibs dipped in deep, rich, organic 70% dark chocolate.

 

What are cocoa nibs?

  • Cacao nibs are pieces of cocoa beans. To make nibs, the beans are first fermented and then dried before they’re roasted and cracked. What’s left after the beans have been cracked is a brittle shell, along with the nibs. The shell is removed through a process known as winnowing. The resulting nibs can then be processed into chocolate.



Storage Tips:

  • Nothing beats vacuum sealing for freshness.
  • Store below 15°C and < 65% humidity.
  • Store in the dark as light degrades flavors.
  • Mason jars make great storage containers.
  • Can be frozen to prolong shelf life.

entry.title: Organic Peppermints
entry.summary:
Vendor: OnlineOrganics
Type: Candies & Snacks
Price: 173.68

Our organic peppermints are a classic treat that has rumored have been invented in the 1780. Made in the Netherlands these are premium vegan organic candies with just 3 ingredients.

 

Ingredients:

  • Organic glucose syrup, organic dextrose, organic essential peppermint oil.

 

When were peppermints invented?

  • Altoids, the popular, and curiously strong mints were invented in 1780, long before Pep-O-Mint LifeSavers hit the scene in 1912, and peppermint Pez candies were created in 1927. So, you could go with Altoids as the originator of the peppermint candy, but we wouldn’t call that definitive by any means. Safe guess the next time you’re at trivia? Sure. Stone cold fact? Ehh.



Storage Tips:

  • Store in the dark as light degrades flavors.
  • Mason jars make great storage containers.

entry.title: Organic Veggie Wine Gums
entry.summary:
Vendor: OnlineOrganics
Type: Candies & Snacks
Price: 110.50

Our organic veggies wine gums are chewy and an overall great treat. Made in Germany these are premium vegan organic candies. For those wondering they do not contain actual alcohol...

 

Ingredients:

  • Organic glucose syrup, organic cane sugar (unrefined), organic corn starch, organic wine 9,4%, organic fruit juice concentrates 3,5% (organic pineapple 0,61%, organic apple 0,61%, organic raspberry 0,61%, organic black currant 0,61%, organic lemon 0,53%, organic orange 0,53%), acidulant (citric acid), natural flavors, coloring fruit and plant extracts (alga, saflor, organic carrot, organic pumpkin, organic apple, organic elderberry), gelling agent (pectin), acidity regulator (sodium citrate), coating agent (organic carnauba wax).

 

Why are wine gums called this way?

  • The son of a London sweetshop owner, Charles Gordon Maynard wanted to create a sweet that could be savored like a fine wine. The "wine gum" plan nearly backfired because his father, Charles Riley Maynard was a strict Methodist teetotaler who threatened to expel him from the business for introducing wine to his products. But the "wine" label was merely a ruse. The only flavorings his wine gums contained were derived from fruit. Launched by Maynard’s in 1909, by 2002 they were selling more than £40 million a year.



Storage Tips:

    • Store in the dark as light degrades flavors.
    • Mason jars make great storage containers.
